abstract.text: A sample of procedural noise data from which you can read noise values directly or create noise textures.

inlineContent.text: Working with procedural noise involves three main steps, one of each of the three major GameplayKit noise classes:
Noise sources (the
class cluster) represent the core algorithms and parameters for generating noise. You choose a general style of noise by instantiating and configuring one of the concrete
subclasses.
Noise objects (

instances) represent the field of noise generated by a noise source. You create a noise object from a noise source, and can then process it or combine it with other noise objects to create more complex noise patterns. Noise objects are lightweight: GameplayKit defers the computation of generating noise and applying noise processing operations until you’re ready to create output.
objects are the concrete output of noise generation and processing. Creating a noise map performs the computation described by the
and
objects you create it from, filling a 2D grid of a specific size with noise values based on a slice of the noise object’s 3D noise field.
You can apply noise maps in many different ways. Some examples include :

Creating texture images resembling natural phenomena such as clouds, stone surfaces, and wood grain. You can also use noise textures as normal maps to make surfaces appear more natural under lighting. (See the
method.)

Generating procedural game-world maps resembling natural terrain. You can create game world of infinite size by using procedural noise as its underlying representation, and manage storage and memory efficiently by creating noise maps (and their visual representations) only for the area around a player’s current position. (See the
class.)
Adding a degree of randomness to otherwise smooth movements. For example, you can make game characters move in a jittery manner, or apply a hand-held motion effect to a game camera.
The content of a noise map is a field of floating-point values that, by default, range from
to
. You can access these values individually with the
and
methods, or create SpriteKit resources from the entire noise map’s values with the methods mentioned above.

A noise map is finite and two-dimensional, but the the noise you sample to create it is three-dimensional and infinite in extent. You can create interesting effects by transforming noise in three dimensions before creating a noise map. For example:
By using a cylindrical noise source and applying the
method, you can sample a slice through the cylinders that creates a wood-grain effect.
By using a Perlin noise source and applying the
method between multiple samples, you can animate a noise map that simulates the way clouds form, billow, and dissipate over time.

abstract.text: An image, decoded on the GPU, that can be used to render various SpriteKit objects.
Creates a texture from the specified noise map.
Architect and organize your game logic. Incorporate common gameplay behaviors such as random number generation, artificial intelligence, pathfinding, and agent behavior.
A procedural noise generator whose output is a type of fractal coherent noise with smooth features.
A procedural noise generator whose output is an alternating square pattern.
The abstract superclass for procedural noise generators that create coherent noise.
A procedural noise generator that outputs a field of a single constant value.
A procedural noise generator whose output is a 3D field of concentric cylindrical shells.
A representation of procedural noise, generated by a noise source, that you can use to process, transform, or combine noise.
Translates the entire noise field by the specified x, y, and z offsets.
Rotates the entire noise field by the specified x, y, and z angles.
A sample of procedural noise data from which you can read noise values directly or create noise textures.
Initializes a noise map with a constant noise value of zero throughout.
Initializes a noise map by sampling from the specified noise object.
Creates a noise map by sampling from the specified noise object.
Returns the value at the specified position in the noise map, interpolating results for positions not on the discrete sample grid.
A Boolean value indicating whether the noise map’s output can repeat seamlessly in all directions.
Creates a noise map by sampling from the specified noise object.
Creates a noise map by sampling from the specified noise object.
The position of the “slice” of noise samples contained in the noise map relative to the unit coordinate space of the noise object it was created from.
The width and height of integer grid for which the noise map contains sampled noise values.
Sets the value at the specified position in the noise map.
The size of the “slice” of noise samples contained in the noise map relative to the unit coordinate space of the noise object it was created from.
Returns the value at the specified position in the noise map’s discrete sample grid.
The abstract superclass for procedural noise generators.
A procedural noise generator whose output is a type of fractal coherent noise resembling natural phenomena such as clouds and terrain.
A procedural noise generator whose output is a type of multifractal coherent noise with sharply defined features.
A procedural noise generator whose output is a 3D field of concentric spherical shells.
A procedural noise generator whose output (also called Worley noise or cellular noise) divides space into discrete cells surrounding random seed points.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
